content: The Act titled "Incentivize Growth Now In Tomorrow's Entrepreneurs Act of 2017" introduces Small Business Start-Up Savings Accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This new part allows for the establishment of savings accounts specifically for small business start-ups. The Act "Incentivize Growth Now In Tomorrow's Entrepreneurs Act of 2017" introduces Small Business Start-Up Savings Accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A small business start-up savings account is exempt from taxation but subject to taxes on unrelated business income. It is a trust created for qualified start-up expenditures of the designated beneficiary, meeting specific requirements. The Act "Incentivize Growth Now In Tomorrow's Entrepreneurs Act of 2017" introduces Small Business Start-Up Savings Accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Contributions to the account must be in cash and limited to the lesser of $10,000 or the individual's gross income. The trustee must be a bank or demonstrate compliance with trust requirements, and trust funds cannot be invested in life insurance contracts. The trust assets must not be commingled except in a common trust fund or common investment fund. Qualified start-up expenditures are defined as per section 195 and include the taxpayer's share of expenses of an entity they hold interest in. However, this term does not apply if the business has more than 50 full-time employees in a taxable year. Tax Treatment of Distributions: Any distribution is taxable under section 72. No income tax is due if qualified start-up expenses equal or exceed distributions. Excess distributions reduce taxable income. The text discusses the tax treatment of distributions, stating that any distribution is taxable under section 72. It mentions that no income tax is due if qualified start-up expenses equal or exceed distributions, and excess distributions reduce taxable income. Additionally, it explains the disallowance of excluded amounts as deductions, credits, or exclusions for qualified start-up expenditures. For a taxable year, distributions from small business start-up savings accounts are exempt from paragraph (1) if received by the individual before the filing deadline with accompanying net income from excess contributions. Excess contribution refers to any contribution exceeding the allowable amount for the taxable year. Rollover contribution allows for funds to be transferred to a small business start-up savings account within 60 days. Transfer of an individual's interest in a small business start-up savings account to a spouse or former spouse under a divorce or separation instrument is not taxable. After the transfer, the account is treated as if the spouse is the account beneficiary. If a surviving spouse acquires the interest in a small business start-up savings account after the account beneficiary's death, the account is treated as if the spouse were the beneficiary. In other cases where someone else acquires the account beneficiary's interest, the account ceases to be a small business start-up savings account. If a surviving spouse or estate inherits a small business start-up savings account, the fair market value of the assets in the account on the date of death is includible in the gross income of the inheritor for the taxable year. Special rules apply in such cases. Special rules apply for reducing inclusion of predeath expenses in gross income and allowing deductions for estate taxes under certain circumstances. The section allows for deductions for estate taxes under certain circumstances, without consideration of community property laws. Custodial accounts can be treated as trusts if certain conditions are met, except for the fact that it is not a trust, constitute a small business start-up account described in subsection (a). The custodian of such account shall be treated as the trustee thereof. Adjustments for inflation are made in the dollar amount in subsection (b)(1) for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2017. The trustee of a small business start-up savings account must report contributions, distributions, and other relevant matters to the Secretary and the account holder. Reports must be filed and furnished to individuals by January 31 of the following year. Regulations will be issued by the Secretary. The Secretary will issue regulations for reporting qualified start-up expenditures of an entity. Section 4975 of the Code is amended to include a small business start-up savings account. Regulations for reporting contributions and distributions must be followed. Code is amended to exempt individuals and contributors to small business start-up savings accounts from certain taxes under section 530A(d)(1) or for qualified start-up expenditures. Additionally, reporting requirements for small business start-up savings accounts are updated under section 6693(a) of the Code. The Code is amended to exempt individuals and contributors to small business start-up savings accounts from certain taxes. Reporting requirements for these accounts are also updated. Excess contributions to small business start-up savings accounts are defined as the amount contributed exceeding the allowable contribution limit, plus any excess from the previous year, minus distributions and any additional contributions. Excess contributions to small business start-up savings accounts are defined as the amount contributed exceeding the allowable contribution limit for the taxable year. Any contribution distributed from the account in a certain manner will be treated as an amount not contributed. Effective Date: The amendments for Small Business Start-Up Savings Accounts apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2016.
